ratings.comment: Easily my favorite STEM professor at Madison so far. Funny and passionate dude who grades extremely fairly with a generous curve. Lots of small tests instead of big midterms. Lectures are never boring, but he does go on tangents fairly often.
What more could you ask when there is no midterm + 80 is a A + 50% of the grade is free if you do homeworks and go to labs?

Prof Walker sometimes forgets what actually comes naturally to us, especially since some of us only took introductory HS physics before this course. He also goes on tangents unrelated to the lecture itself which can leave you wondering what you were supposed to learn. Otherwise, he is a super nice guy who really wants to help his students succeed!

Nice guy but hard to follow. Very passionate but that often leads to tangents in lectures that involve physics way beyond what we knew. Lectures were a bit hard to follow and often not relevant to what was tested.  

Did his best to help with the grade/relieve pressure. Minimal homework, completion labs and generous curve.

Thad will tell you that everything in the class is easy which, in a sense, it is. However, it's only easy once you understand how to do it and he sometimes struggles to identify what students know and what comes easily/what doesn't. He cares about his students A LOT and wants to help Lectures start strong but get less helpful over time.

Great lectures, lots of short homework assignments, and several quizzes rather than more traditional exams. For learning about an infamously difficult subject like quantum mechanics, Prof Walker is a solid choice.

IMO, Thad's lectures are fairly clear and informative. 2 small-ish HW assignments a week; reasonable once you get a handle on Mathematica. 7 chapter quizzes during the semester (no "exams"), similar to HW & also pretty reasonable. As some others have said, if you study & keep up w/ the material, you'll be fine (you can get a B at the very least).

Homework and exams are clear once you know how to use Mathematica, grading is very reasonable. However, Walker is not very consistent with textbook. The topics covered are the same but the methods they used could be very different. For my semester though, there was this quarantine thing going on, and Walker only posted a 30min video every week.

Thad stands out among the STEM profs I've had so far, but that actually doesn't say much because STEM pedagogy at Madison is usually horrendous. He glosses over many things, but he usually explains concepts much better than average. Homework is harder than exams; I found the exams to be doable and straightforward just from reading the textbook. GL.

He is the reason I will continue on in the field of quantum mechanics in physics graduate school.  He told our class he thinks of us as his surrogate children.  He's great and clearly cares about his students!  He trained us well.  Best class ever !
Great professor and a nice guy. Should be an easy class as long as you keep up to date.

One of the greatest professors I have got. Thad is very helpful during his office hours. Homework and exams are formidable; nevertheless, if you dedicate your time into it, they can be surmounted. Stay inquisitive and stay diligent!

Thad's quantum seems overly tough and not fun while you're taking it, but you will thank him later. The class is easy to do well in if you study your butt off, which you will have to do to learn the difficult material. It's a hard class but by far my favorite physics class(es) I've taken at Madison. You will learn A LOT.

Not the best. We go very quickly and are sometimes taught material not in the textbook. He provides some horribly commented notes online that only serve to confuse you more. He screws up his examples quite a bit in class, and if the bell rings before he finishes, he completely disregards the topic in future classes. He also switches notation a lot.
He is a good lecturer, has office hours every day of week to help with any problems you're having with the homeworks or class in general.

The hardest and most rewarding classes I've ever taken. Thad has office hours every morning and makes an amazing effort to make difficult concepts clear. He is a hard professor, but he is without question the best professor I've ever had.     Go to class and go to office hours and you'll be fine. If you survive you'll get an AB, B at worst.

Extremely willing to provide help if you don't understand something. Sometimes has trouble remembering back when he didn't know something, and has trouble connecting with students' misunderstanding, but still tries as hard as he can to grant understanding. Well designed course, but a thad unorganized (punny!).

Terrible.  Does not explain things clearly, and uses his own methods and notation, so the book (while excellent) is of no help for the exams.  No help outside of class, often turning students away so he can "get his own work done".  A significant portion of the class dropped after first semester of two semester sequence to avoid having Thad again.

one complaint: drops terms all over the place. That being said, Thad explains the concepts well, going beyond the book in depth, especially when it came to explaining the use of Mathematica for problem solving (essential for quantum). Quite willing to give students time outside of class to explain the material.

Bad Professor! He picked an old text book for the class that is from 2000 and its 2009. His handwriting isn?t clear at all. A total failure at communication with students. Do not ask him questions as he will tell you stop taking up enough of my time get out my office! Asinine and Condescending! Passed his course, but fire this man for disrespect.

His choice in a book was absolutely terrible. He definitely understood the material and TRIED explaining it, he just failed passing his knowledge to the students. He treated us as we were grad students in physics when we were just in an introductary class. BE PREPARED FOR A STRUGGLE IF YOU CHOOSE TO TAKE HIS CLASS.

His first time teaching the course. Terrible experience. Used practice problems from 10+ years ago and didn't know how to solve them. He is unapproachable and pretty bad at answering questions. Hates engineers, beware.

I'm sure Thad is an expert in Physics, but that's his greatest downfall. Socially challenged, he has difficulty answering questions, spelling, and showing things. He skips so many steps when he's "showing" that he often loses variables and negative signs... as if I weren't confused enough. He tries, but definitely shouldn't teach an intro course.

He teaches physics exactly the way I think about it. He explained things perfectly for me.  His love of the subject is overwhelming, and he is clearly very knowledgeable on the subject.  Perhaps his lectures are a little disorganized and his demos work only half of the time, but this was an amazing class.  I learned so much!!

Tests are ridiculously hard and homework isn't much easier. He'll give a lot of partial credit on tests, but homework scores are brutal. He gets nervous during demos, which is always good for a laugh. The demos are usually pretty cool, too. He's not the best at explaining things, though, and fails miserably in his attempts to be funny. Oh well.

Wasn't the greatest, I definitely would NOT take a course from him again.  He seems to try, but it just doesn't come through.  Also the exams were most of the time ridiculous, they were ones that really pushed you to 'see if you REALLY understand whats going on'
His tests are WAY too difficult.  Everyone scores extremely poorly on them and then he has to apply a huge curve. If you ask him a question he usually acts snooty to you.

During lecture he just reads off the contents of his power point slides.  Quite boring although good for people who like to skip class.  Exams are way too hard for this level of a class.  We talked about triple integrals and gradients so I feel bad for anyone who hasn't had Math 234 yet.

very hard to pay attention to. tests written for upper level classes, end up with ridiculous curves. useless homework nothing like tests. labs are complete useless busy work. the book he assigns for honors is actually very interesting. strange man. would rather have his lab assistant, Steve, as professor.

Better than Everett. Great demos, even when one messes up or he does it twice and forgets he did it. First 2 exams were a piece of cake. Not too much HW. More confidence in lecture than Everett. He's nice, doesn't expect TOO much, and is always excited in lecture. Example problems are pointed and well executed.
He's a nice guy, but I really didn't care for his teaching style. I did not findit at all helpful. Funny at times though.

He's the rock god of physics in my opinion. A thoroughly inspiring lecturer. Large amounts of complex and difficult homework. Tests that...well, they're pretty darn hard, but they're hard for everyone and the more you think about the concepts the better you will do. Take him if you can cuz you will take away from his class a ton,including his units

The pace of lecture was way too fast and the tests were way too hard.  I didnt understand most of the stuff he taught in lecture so I tried to depend solely on the book, which didnt help come exam time.  I would advise only to take this class if you know youre a physics wizz.  otherwise, try a lower sequence

I had Thad for the 247-8-9 sequence and was very happy with him.  His tests are hard, but he always curves them pretty nicely.  He assigns a lot of homework, but is always open to help you if you ask.  He lectures at a faster pace, but was clear on all the topics taught.  I would recommend him to anyone interested in physics.
Thad lectures at a very fast pace and assigns hard homework. He's sometimes a little unapproachable but he's always helpful. He's a nice guy and you could get a lot worse in a professor.

He gives tough exams, but will give you all the help you want if you ask for it. Jokes around at times, but still gets down to business. His ego does take a hit, however, if people score nearly perfect on his exams. Mention C=1 and you'll be good to go.
